files.fulltext:
A MANUAL

OF

THE CHURCH OF CHRIST,

A

A \

' MILLIS, MAs|. P 3 1890 J

1714 -OCTOBER SEVENTH - 1889.

EDITED BY E. O. JAMESON, PASTOR.

BOSTON:

ALFRED MUDGE & SON, PRINTERS, No. 24 Franklin Street.

1 890 .

HISTORY.

This Church of Christ was established by public worship, ou Sunday, the seventh day of October, 1714. The service was con- ducted in the dwelling-house of Peter Adams by the Rev. David Deming, who, the next year, was ordained and installed its first pastor.

The records of the church, during the first pastorate, have been lost ; hence the names of the early members are to some extent unknown. But from the church records of Medfield, to which town this locality belonged for seventy years prior to the incorporation of Medway, have been gathered the names of those of that church who w r ere then resident within the limits of the new town, and must have constituted the larger part of the members of this church at its organization.

From the commencement of the second pastorate, in 1724, the records are well preserved, and contain the doings of the church, with lists of the names of the members and of the baptized children.

There have been settled nine pastors, whose active ministrations cover a period of one hundred and sixty-five of the one hundred and seventy-five years since the church was established. The Rev. Nathan Bucknam was pastor for seventj-one years, being in active service sixty-two years.

Twenty- three persons have served as deacons, three of whom are now in office, and the others have died.

The whole number of admissions, so far as recorded, is eight hun- dred and twenty-six. The present membership is one hundred and twenty-six: thirty-eight males and eighty-eight females. There are thirty-one non-resident members, and fifteen who are retired by reason of age and infirmities, and very rarely can attend public worship. This leaves a present active membership of eighty persons, of whom twenty-two are males and fifty-eight females.

This church has sustained a Sunday school for* over seventy years and a branch Sunday school for more than thirty years. The num- ber connected with these schools, at this date, is one hundred and

6

seventy. The main school has one hundred and twenty-six, and the branch school has forty-four, including teachers and scholars.

There have been four meeting-houses erected and occupied for public worship. The first was built in 1715, and stood for thirty-four years, when it was destroyed by fire. The second was occupied for sixty-seven years, the third for thirty-four years, and the present house has been in use for forty years.

Several seasons of religious revival have occurred. The most re- markable was in 1837, when at one communion service forty-six per- sons were received to the church. For more than a hundred years, candidates were received on giving assent publicly to the covenant, but since 1836 a confession of faith and a revised form of the ancient covenant have been in use.

The one hundred and sixty-second anniversary of the church was observed Oct. 7, 1876, the year of our national centennial, by special services. Three ex-pastors were present, Revs. Sewall Harding, John O. Means, D. D., and Jacob Roberts. The historical discourse on that occasion, preached by the pastor, was published. The one hundred and seventy-fifth anniversary was observed by appropriate public service on Sunday, Oct. 6, and a social reunion of members, past and present, on Monday, Oct. 7, 1889, with invited guests.

At a church meeting, held Aug. 3, 1889, the pastor and deacons were appointed a committee to revise the church manual. They com- pleted their work, and the present manual was approved by the church, June 7, 1890, and ordered to be printed.

Parsonage Erectkd in 1872

DOCTRINES

1. There is only one true God x , revealed as the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit 2 ; the Creator 3 and Ruler 4 of the Universe; a Being of infinite wisdom 5 , power 0 , justice 7 , goodness 8 , mercy 9 , and truth 10 ; and the only proper object of religious worship n .

Scriptural References.

(1) Heb. xi. 6; Detit. iv. 35, 39; Deut. vi. 4; Jer. x. 10.

(2) Gen. i. 26 ; Matt, xxviii. 19 ; 1 Cor. viii. 4.

(3) Gen. i. 1-31; Nell. ix. 6; John i. 1-3; Col. i. 16; Heb. i. 3; Heb. iii.

4; Rev. iv. 11.

(4) Ps. lxxxiii. 18; cxlvii. 15; Prov. xvi. 9,33; Isa. ix. 6, 7; Eph. i.

11; Phil. ii. 13.

(5) Job xii. 13 ; Ps. cxxxix. 1-12; cxlvii. 5 ; Acts xv. 18 ; Rom. xi. 33 ; xvi.

27 ; 1 John i. 5 ; Jude i. 25.

(6) Gen. xvii. 1 ; Job xlii. 2 ; Matt. xix. 26 ; Rev. iv. 8 ; xix. 6.

(7) Ex. xxxiv. 7; Deut. xxxii. 4

(8) Ex. xxxiv. 6; Ps. cxlv. 9.

(9) Ex. xxxiv. 6; John iii. 16, 17 : xv. 13; Eph. ii. 4; 1 John iv. 16.

(10) Deut. xxxii. 4; Ps. cxlv. 17; Prov. xxx. 5.

(11) Deut. vi. 13, 14; Matt. iv. 10; John iv. 24; Rev. xix. 10.

2. The Holy Scriptures were given by inspiration of God x , and are the only perfect rule of religious faith and practice 2 .

Scriptural References.

(1) 2 Tim. iii. 16; Heb. i. 1, 2; 2 Peter i. 21.

(2) Ps. xii. 16; xix. 7; cxix. 105; Isa. viii. 20; Gal. i. 8; 2 Tim. iii.

15-17; 2 Peter i. 19-21.

8

3. Our first parents were created in the image of Goc] 1 , that they might know, love, obey, and enjoy Him forever 2 , but they trans- gressed the Divine command 3 and fell into condemnation and mis- ery 4 . And in consequence of their sin all mankind, by nature, are alienated from God and inclined to evil 5 .

Scriptural Beferences.

(1) Gen. i. 27; Gen. v. 1, 2; Ecc. vii. 29.

(2) Job xxxii. 8; John xvii. 3; Rom. i. 19, 20.

(3) Gen. iii. 3, 6; Rom. v. 12; 1 John iii. 4.

(4) Gen. iii. 16-19 ; Rom. viii. 22.

(5) Gen. v. 3; Ps. li. 5; lviii. 3-5; Rom. i. 28; Eph. ii. 3; iv. 18, 19;

Col. i. 21 ; Titus iii. 3.

4. The Lord Jesus Christ, God manifest in the flesh 1 , has by His life, sufferings, death, and resurrection, provided a way of reconcilia- tion for the whole world 2 and secured the forgiveness and salvation of every penitent believer 3 .

Scriptural Beferences.

(1) Isa. ix. G, 7; John i. 1, 14; x. 33, 36; Rom. ix. 5; 1 Tim. iii. 16;

Heb. ii. 16.

(2) Isa. liii. 4-9; Matt. xxvi. 28; Rom. iii. 24; Eph. i. 7; Phil. ii. 7, 8;

1 Tim. i. 15; ii. 5; Heb. ii. 9, 10; vii. 26; 1 John ii. 2.

(3) Isa. xlv. 21, 22; liii. 11; lv. 3, 6; John vi. 35; vii. 37, 38; Heb. ii. 9,

10; Rev. xxii. 17.

5. Those who do truly repent of sin and believe the Gospel are renewed in heart by the work of the Holy Spirit 1 , and all such are kept by the grace of God through their faith unto salvation 2 .

Scriptural Beferences.

(1) John i. 12, 13; iii. 3; vi. 45; Rom. xii. 2; Gal. v. 22-25; Titus iii. 5; 1 Peter i. 23 ; 1 John iii. 14 ; v. 4, 20.

Job xvii. 9; Ps. xxxvii. 23, 24; cxxv. 1, 2; Prov. ii. 8; Isa. liv. 7; Jer. xxxii. 40; John iv. 14; vi. 35, 37, 39, 40, 54-58; x. 27, 28; 1 Cor. i. 8, 9; x. 13; Col. iii. 4; 1 Thess. v. 9, 10; 2 Thess. iii. 3; 1 Peter i. 5.

( 2 )

9

6. It is the privilege of parents and*heads of families who are confessedly in covenant with God to consecrate their children and all under their parental care to the Lord in the rite of Christian baptism 1 ; and their duty to train them up in the knowledge and ser- vice of the Lord 2 .

Scriptural References.

(1) Luke xviii. 15, 16; Acts ii. 38, 39; Acts xvi. 15, 33; 1 Cor. i. 16.

(2) Deut. vi. 6-9 ; Prov. xxii. 6 ; Eph. vi. 4 ; 1 Tim. iii. 4-17.

7. After death there will be a resurrection 1 and a final judg ment 2 : when those whom Christ condemns will go away into ever- lasting punishment 3 , but the righteous into life eternal 4 .

Scriptural References.

(1) Dan. xii. 2, 3; Matt. xxii. 29-33; Matt, xxvii. 52, 53; John v. 28, 29;

John xi. 23-26 ; 1 Cor. xv. 20-22, 49-54.

(2) Ps. ix. 7, 8; xcvi. 13; Ecc. xi. 9; xii. 14; Matt. xii. 36; John iv. 22;

Acts x. 42; Rom. ii. 5-11 ; xiv. 10, 12; 2 Cor. v. 10; 2 Tim. iv. 1; Heb. ix. 27; Rev. xx. 12, 13; xxii. 11-14.

(3) Job xxxi. 2, 3; Matt. x. 28; xiii. 30, 40, 41, 49-51; xxv. 30-46;

Mark xvi. 16; Rom. ii. 5-9; 2 Cor. v. 10; 2 Thess. i. 8, 9;

2 Peter iii. 7 ; Rev. xxi. 8.

(4) Ps. xvi. 11; lxxiii. 24; Dan. xii. 3; Matt. xiii. 43; xix. 29; Luke xii

30 ; John iii. 14-16 ; 2 Cor. v. 1, 8, 9 ; 2 Tim. iv. 8 ; 1 Peter i. 3-5 ; v. 4; Rev. ii. 10; iii. 5, 12, 21 ; vii. 9-17; xxi. 4, 27; xxii. 5, 14.

[TO THE CANDIDATE.]

Do these statements represent your religious belief ?

ADMISSION

Beloved : You do believe in the Christian Church, in its ordinances and in its fellowship, and you now desire to confess Christ publicly, and to enter into covenant with God and this Church?

Ido .

CONFESSION.

Do you receive and confess Jesus Christ as your Saviour, Teacher, and Lord?

Ido.

BAPTISM.

Upon this confession of Christ you will now receive Baptism, or, if baptized in childhood, accept the parental act by which you were then consecrated to the Lord.

[candidates kneeling, the kite is administered.]

Having expressed your desire to enter into the covenant with God and this Church, you will now take upon you the avowed obligations and receive the declared assurances of the following Covenant.

COVENANT.

Whereas, God has granted unto you the forgiveness of sins, by His grace in Jesus Christ through faith in Him, and has promised to bestow all needed help to overcome evil unto Christian holiness and eternal life ;

You do hereby publicly covenant with Him to rely on His promises of grace, to seek His help, and to consecrate yourself, your posses- sions, and your influence to His service and glory forever.

Ido.

11

And whereas this Church has invited you to enter into its Covenant and fellowship ;

You do hereby publicly accept its invitation, and confess your sin- cere desire to be received into its membership and communion, to come under its care and discipline, to share its worship, its prayers, its ordinances, its love, its labors, its responsibilities, its sacrifices, and its joys.

And you promise to conduct yourself as a Christian disciple, to live as an heir of the grace of life, and to walk in all faithfulness to these Covenant obligations as a member of this Church, and in loving fellowship with all disciples of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.

With these pledges and assurances, you ask to be received in the exercise of Christian charity, patience, love, and good fidelity, as a member of this Church ?

Ido.

[THE CHURCH WILL THEN RI8E.]

We, the members of this Church, upon this public avowal of your desire and purposes, do hereby receive you most cordially to our membership and to our fellowship, to enjoy with us all the privileges of this Church, to share with us its labors, responsibilities, sacrifices, and joys. And by the help of the Divine Spirit and the enlighten- ment of God’s Word we hereby promise to act toward you, individu- ally and together, in all Christian love and confidence, to the end that you and we may become more and more established in the faith and in the service of the Gospel, to the mutual edifying of one another in the love and fellowship and grace of Jesus Christ, to whom be the o-lorv forever. Amen.

o 4.

(THE MINISTER WILL HERE SAY:]

Beloved, — In the name of Christ, I now extend to you the right hand of Christian fellowship, and welcome you to all the privileges and duties of membership in this Church of Christ and in God’s household of faith.

“ The Lord bless thee and keep thee;

“ The Lord m jJce his face to shine upon thee , and be gracious unto thee ;

“ The Lord lift up his countenance upon thee and give thee peace .”

REGULATIONS

1. This Church is Congregational in polity, and shall be governed by the teachings of the New Testament and the usages of the early churches of New England.

2. Its permanent officers are a Pastor and two or more Deacons.

3. The regular meetings for business shall be held monthly, on the Friday next preceding the first Sunday in each month. The annual meeting shall be held on the Friday next before the first Sunday in February of each year. Special meetings may be called by the Pas- tor or any one of the Deacons. At meetings for business the Pastor shall preside, and in his absence the senior Deacon.

4. All collections of money shall be received, disbursed, and ac- counted for by the Deacons, who are also the Trustees of the perma- nent funds of the Church. At the annual meeting, by some one of their number as Treasurer, they shall make a complete report of all receipts and disbursements of money, duly attested by Auditors. The Deacons shall also have in charge the records and other Church papers ; one of them, acting as Clerk, shall keep a careful minute of the doings of the Church, record the names of members, and enter any other items of interest in a book kept for the purpose.

5. The male and female members of legal age shall have the same right to vote in all Church affairs.

6. An Executive Committee shall consist of the Pastor, the Deacons, with two brothers and two sisters to be chosen annually. This com- mittee shall examine candidates, and have a general supervision of the interests of the Church, and bring forward any matters for con- sideration and action.

7. The election of Sunday School Superintendent and Assistant Superintendent shall be subject to the approval of the Church. The Superintendent shall make an annual report of the School to the Church.

8. There shall be chosen annually as many Auditors as the laws of this Commonwealth require.

13

9. The members of other churches in fellowship with us, resident here, on the presentation of letters of dismission and recommenda- tion, in the usual form, from the churches to which they belong, shall be received by vote. All resident Christians shall receive the cordial recognition of the members of this Church, and be invited to attend our religious services and to come into covenant with us.

10. The qualifications for membership are, credible evidence of repentance and of faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, an assent to the Doctrines, and a willingness to enter into the Covenant of this Church.

11. Any persons who desire to become members of this Church, shall meet the Executive Committee, and on their approval they shall be announced to the congregation as candidates two weeks, or in special cases, one week, before they are received, to give the oppor- tunity for any of the Church to satisfy themselves that the proposed candidates are suitable persons for Church membership. And by a vote of the Church they shall be received on the public confession of Christ and assuming the obligations of the Church Covenant.

12. It shall be the duty of the members of this Church to take an interest in all persons who do not attend public worship, and invite them to our religious services, seeking in every possible way their spiritual welfare.

13. Letters of dismission and recommendation, on request, shall be granted in usual form to members in good standing, residing elsewhere, who may wish to unite with other churches. Those absent are expected to report their residences to the Clerk.

14. Besides the public worship of G-od on Sundays, there shall be held such other religious meetings as the Church may see fit to appoint and attend.

15. The Sacrament of our Lord’s Supper shall be celebrated on the first Sundays of January, March, May, July, September, and November. And on the Friday next preceding the Sacramental Sunday, in connection with the monthly business meeting, there shall be a religious service with reference to a preparation for the Lord’s Supper.

16. All members shall pay for the support of the institutions of religion, here and elsewhere, as there is need and they have the means. Annual contributions shall be made for carrying on the Christian work of the following societies, viz. : —

14

The Seamen’s Friend Society .... The Home Missionary Society .

The Foreign Missionary Society

The American Education Society

The New West Commission Society

The American Missionary Association Society,

To be collected in February. To be collected in April.

To be collected in June.

To be collected in August.

To be collected in October. To be collected in December.

17. There shall be made occasional contributions to other worthy objects, as the opportunity may offer and demand.

18. Members of suitable age and qualifications are expected to become members of the Parish connected with the Church.

19. There shall be held a Social Reunion of the Church annually on the seventh day of October, as an anniversary of its organ- ization.

20. These regulations may be altered or amended by a two-thirds vote of the members present at any regular meeting, provided a notice of the proposed change has been introduced at a previous meeting.

APPENDIX.

ANCIENT CHURCH COVENANT.

Medfield, Mass.

1651 - 1714 .

“ You do now present yourself before the Lord an < l his people, professing a firm and serious belief of the Scriptures as the word of God, and making a steady pro- fession of the Christian religion as therein contained.

“ You do give up yourself to God in an everlasting covenant through Jesus Christ, solemnly promising, by the assistance of divine grace, that you will renounce the sins and vanities of the present evil world ; that you will, as God shall enable you, repent of all your past sins, and live for time to come in conformity to the rules of our holy religion.

“ You do give yourself up to the Lord Jehovah, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, as your best good and last end.

“ You give yourself up to the Lord Jesus Christ as your Prophet, Priest, and King, and to the Holy Ghost as your Sanctifier, Guide, and Comforter.”

Admission by the Half-Way Covenant.

“You submit yourself to the laws of Christ ' s kingdom as they are administered among this people, giving up yourself to the watch and discipline of this Church. You promise that you will diligently labor after those higher attainments in Christian grace and knowledge, whereby you may in some measure be qualified for and in due time be encouraged to come up to the table of the Lord.”

Baptism.

“ Now, then, in testimony of your setting your seal to this holy Covenant, and consenting to the holy duties of it, and, further, to assure you the actual benefits and privileges of this Covenant, if you be sincere in this dedication and surrender of yourself in the exercise of true repentance and faith unfeigned, I shall baptize you, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.”

52

After Baptism.

“ You have now given up your name to God ; and, in a very solemn manner, sub- scribed his holy Covenant, and you are to remember that henceforward the eyes of the Lord, holy and jealous, are upon you to observe whether you keep this Covenant and perform the vows of the Lord which are upon you. If you deal falsely, and break his Covenant by living in sin and neglect of duty, what you have now done will be a witness against you. But if you do faithfully keep this your Covenant, departing from the ways of sin, and living in the exercise of holiness, you may hope for the good things of this life with the tokens of covenant love, and in the world to come be brought to possess an inheritance incorruptible, undefiled, and which cannot fade away.

“ And that you may be enabled to keep this your Covenant, and perform the vows of the Lord which are upon you, we shall now commend you to the grace of God.”

Admission to Full Communion.

“You do also give yourself up to this Church in the Lord, and according to the will of God you promise and covenant through grace to cleave to us and walk together with us as a member of the same mystical body and as an instituted Church of Christ : and so to walk together with us in love and holy watchfulness, with a sincere subjection of your soul to the power of the Lord Jesus Christ in the regular administration of all his holy ordinances and in the full exercise of his holy rules and government in this Church in a way of order, peace, and union.

“ Thus you covenant ? ”

Restipulation.

“ We do then acknowledge you as a member of the same body with ourselves. And in the name of this Church, I promise that by the assistance of the Lord we will watch towards you in love and holy watchfulness, to the mutual building up of one another in the faith and fellowship of the Gospel, earnestly praying that the Lord God will delight to dwell among us, that his glorious kingdom maybe advanced in us and by us, and that he would build us up in holiness and comfort through faith unto everlasting life. Amen.”

“ Med field, 13 th Feb., 1825. — The Covenant above written does not appear on any book of record. The subscriber took it from the blank leaves of an old Psalm Book. It is the one always used by my predecessor, Rev. Dr. T. Prentiss. It is supposed to be the only one ever used in the church. . . .

, DANIEL C. SANDERS.”

(Signed)

53

FIRST COVENANT OF THE CHURCH.

1714-1837.

The Covenant to be propounded to those that are admitted to the ordinance of the Lord’s Supper : —

You are now in full communion with the Church of Christ, purchased with the price of his blood, and you do now seriously, freely, and forever, in the presence of God, by whom you expect shortly to be judged, and by whom you hope to be acquitted, and in the presence of an innumerable company of elect angels, and in presence of this assembly, give up yourself to God the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, avouching the Lord Jehovah to be your God; you give up yourself to the Lord Jesus Christ as unto your Prophet, Priest, and King forever, promising by the assistance of the Spirit of Grace to walk iu all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless, answerable to the high and holy vocation wherewith you are called. You give up yourself and posterity to this Church, submitting to the rule aud discipline of it, putting yourself under the watch and care of it, promising to embrace its counsels aud reproofs with hurriility and thankfulness (vide Half-Way Covenant), and duly to attend the ordinances of Christ in this Church, as long as your opportunity thereby to be edified in your holy faith shall be continued to you.

This you promise ?

We, then, the Church of Christ in this place, do joyfully aud charitably receive you into our sacred fellowship and communion as one whom we hope and trust the Lord hath received ; and we promise to admit you to all the ordinances of the Gospel in fellowship with ourselves, and to watch over you with a spirit of meekness, love, and tenderness, as your holy relation unto us calls for ; and to continue our ardent prayers to the God of all grace for you, that you may have grace to keep the Cove- nant that you have now, in so solemn a manner, before angels and us, entered into, that the sure mercies of the everlasting Covenant may be your portion. Amen.

Half-Way Covenant.

1714-1800.

To them that come under the bonds of the Covenant, immediately after the word “ thankfulness ” in the above Covenant, add : —

You promise to attend the worship of God with us so long as Divine Providence shall give opportunity, and take all possible care to prepare yourself for the holy sacrament of the Lord’s Supper ; and when you have reason to think, by the bless- ing of God upon your diligent endeavors, you are in some good measure qualified therefor, you will renew covenant with God and wait upon Him iu that holy insti- tution, and walk as becomes a Christian in all holy conversation and godliness.

This is ivhat you consent to and promise ? Which being done, it follows : —

We, the Church of Christ in this place, acknowledge your covenant relations, and do now take you under our Christian watch and care, promising to admit you to all those privileges that this your sacred relation doth or may entitle you unto, and to watch over you with a spirit of meekness, love, and tenderness, as the Gospel enjoins us, and to continue our ardent prayers to the God of all grace for you that you may have grace to keep this Covenant that you have in so solemn a manner entered into ; that the sure mercies of the everlasting Covenant may be your portion. Amen.

54

FIRST CONFESSION OF FAITH.

1837 - 1890 .

Article I. — We believe there is only one true God, the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost; a Being of infinite wisdom, power, justice, goodness, and truth; and the only proper object of religious worship.

Article II. — That God is the Creator and sovereign Disposer of all creatures and events.

Article III. — That the Holy Scriptures were given by inspiration of God; and are the only perfect rule of religious faith and practice.

Article IV. — That our first parents were created in the image of God, per- fectly holy and happy, and that by transgressing the divine command, they fell into a state of sin and misery.

Article V. — That in consequence of their apostasy, all men are by nature wholly destitute of true holiness, enemies to God, and under the curse of the Divine law.

Article VI. — That the Lord Jesus Christ, being God and man, mysteriously united in one person, has, by his sufferings and death, made an atonement for sin, which is sufficient for the whole world, and thus rendered it consistent with the holy character of God to pardon and save every penitent believer.

Article VII. — That none do truly repent of sin and believe the Gospel, but those who are renewed in heart by the special influences of the Holy Spirit, accord- ing to the eternal purposes of God ; and that all such will be kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation.

Article VIII. — That it is the duty aiftl privilege of parents and heads of fami- lies, who are visibly in covenant with God, to bring their children, and all under their parental care, to the ordinance of Christian baptism, and to train them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord.

Article IX. — That at the end of time there will be a resurrection of the dead, and a general judgment, when the righteous will be received to everlasting happi- ness, and the wicked doomed to endless misery.

Thus you believe and profess ?

[the rite of baptism administered.]

SECOND COVENANT.

1837 - 1890 .

You do now, in the presence of God, angels, and men, avouch the great Jehovah, Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, to be your God — the object of your supreme affec- tions, and your chosen portion forever. You cordially acknowledge and receive the Lord Jesus Christ, in his mediatorial offices of Prophet, Priest, and King, as your only Saviour and final Judge, and the Holy Spirit as your Sanctifier, Guide, and Comforter. You humbly and cheerfully devote yourselves to God, consecrating your all to his service and glory. You promise to take the Scriptures of the Old and New Testament as the guide of your faith and practice, and by God’s grace assisting you, to walk in all the ordinances of his house blameless, and in obedience to all his holy commands, as they are, or shall be, from time to time made known to you. You do also give up yourselves and children to this Church of Christ, volun- tarily submitting to its rule and discipline — putting yourselves under its watch and care — submitting with humility and thankfulness to its rebukes and reproofs — and solemnly covenanting to strive, as much as in you lies, to promote its peace, edifica- tion, and purity, and to walk with its members in Christian love and faithfulness.

Thus purposing, you do now cordially unite with this Church, promising, by the aids of God’s grace, henceforth to deny all ungodliness and every worldly lust, and to live soberly, righteously, and godly in the world.

Thus you engage and promise ?

We, then, of this Church, do joyfully and charitably receive you into our sacred communion and fellowship ; and we severally promise, with the aid of divine grace, to discharge all duties towards you in Christian love and watchfulness, to the mutual building up of one another in the faith and fellowship of the Lord Jesus Christ and His Gospel.

Now, beloved, you have sworn unto the Lord, and you cannot go back. Wherever you go, these vows will rest upon you. They will follow you through life, and to the bar of God ; and in whatever world you may be fixed, will be upon you to eternity. You can never be again as you have been. Voluntarily and unalterably you have committed yourselves, and henceforth you must be the servants of the Lord.

May the Lord guide and preserve you till death, and at last receive both you and us to that blessed world where our love and joy shall be perfect forever. A men.

Note. — The above Confession of Faith and Covenant were printed in 1837, and reprinted in 1870 without alterations. — [Ed.]
